maml:description.maml:para: Convert a script file to a PowerShell function.

This command takes the body of a script file and wraps it in a function declaration. The command will insert missing elements like cmdletbinding() and comment-based help. You will most likely need to edit and clean up the result in your scripting editor.

If you run this command in the PowerShell ISE or the VS Code PowerShell integrated terminal, you can use the dynamic parameter ToEditor to open a new file with with the output. You can edit and save the file manually.
It is assumed that your script file is complete and without syntax errors.
Enter the path to your PowerShell script file.
What is the name of your new function? It should have a standard Verb-Noun name.
Define an optional alias for your new function.
Enter the path to your PowerShell script file.
What is the name of your new function? It should have a standard Verb-Noun name.
Define an optional alias for your new function.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Convert-ScriptToFunction c:\scripts\Daily.ps1 -name Invoke-DailyTask | Set-Clipboard

dev:remarks.maml:para: Convert Daily.ps1 to a function called Invoke-DailyTask and copy the results to the Windows clipboard. You can then paste the results into scripting editor.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Convert-ScriptToFunction c:\scripts\systemreport.ps1 -name New-SystemReport | Out-File c:\scripts\New-SystemReport.ps1

dev:remarks.maml:para: Convert the SystemReport.ps1 script file to a function called New-SystemReport and save the results to a file.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Convert-ScriptToFunction c:\scripts\systemreport.ps1 -name New-System -alias nsr | Tee-Object -variable f

dev:remarks.maml:para: Convert the script to a function called New-System and tee the output to $f. This will also define an function alias of nsr.

maml:description.maml:para: Export a PowerShell function from a script file.

You should use Export-FunctionFromFile when you want to export PowerShell functions defined in in a single script file, placing each function in its own file. You might want to do this to build or restructure a PowerShell module.

You can export all functions from a file or specific functions. The default behavior is to only export functions that follow a standard verb-noun naming convention. The source must be a .ps1 or .psm1 script file.
If you run this command in the PowerShell ISE or the VS Code integrated PowerShell Terminal, you can use the dynamic parameter Remove to delete the function from the source file.
Specify the .ps1 or .psm1 file with defined functions.
Export all detected functions regardless of name.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specify the output path. The default is the same directory as the .ps1 file.
Pass the output file to the pipeline.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

This is a dynamic parameter that is only available if you are running this command in the PowerShell ISE of the VS Code integrated PowerShell terminal. The function will be deleted from the source file after it has been exported.
Specify the .ps1 or .psm1 file with defined functions.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specify a function by name.
Specify the output path. The default is the same directory as the .ps1 file.
Pass the output file to the pipeline.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

This is a dynamic parameter that is only available if you are running this command in the PowerShell ISE of the VS Code integrated PowerShell terminal. The function will be deleted from the source file after it has been exported.
Export all detected functions regardless of name.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specify a function by name.
Specify the output path. The default is the same directory as the .ps1 file.
Pass the output file to the pipeline.
Specify the .ps1 or .psm1 file with defined functions.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

This is a dynamic parameter that is only available if you are running this command in the PowerShell ISE of the VS Code integrated PowerShell terminal. The function will be deleted from the source file after it has been exported.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Export-FunctionFromFile C:\scripts\MyInternetTools.psm1 -Name get-zipinfo -OutputPath c:\scripts\psinternettools\functions

dev:remarks.maml:para: Export the Get-ZipInfo function from C:\scripts\MyInternetTools.psm1 to its own file. The original file remains unchanged.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Export-FunctionFromFile C:\scripts\MyInternetTools.psm1 -OutputPath c:\scripts\psinternettools\functions

dev:remarks.maml:para: Export all functions that follow the verb-noun naming convention to separate files under C:\Scripts\PSInternetTools\Functions.

maml:description.maml:para: Export a model module layout.

Use Export-ModuleLayout to export a model module directory structure to a json file. You can use Import-ModuleLayout to recreate the layout from the json file. The export process will include not only directories, but also text files like a readme or license file.
Specify the name of the Json file to store the result.
Show the file result.
Specify the model module path.
Define a version number for this layout.
Specify the name of the Json file to store the result.
Show the file result.
Specify the model module path.
Define a version number for this layout.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Export-ModuleLayout c:\work\sample -FilePath c:\work\layout.json -Verbose VERBOSE: Starting Export-ModuleLayout VERBOSE: Exporting directory structure from c:\work\sample VERBOSE: Processing .github VERBOSE: Processing .vscode VERBOSE: Processing docs VERBOSE: Processing en-us VERBOSE: Processing formats VERBOSE: Processing functions VERBOSE: Processing icons VERBOSE: Processing images VERBOSE: Processing samples VERBOSE: Processing tests VERBOSE: Processing types VERBOSE: Processing changelog.md VERBOSE: Processing License.txt VERBOSE: Processing README.md VERBOSE: Processing scratch-changelog.md VERBOSE: Processing .vscode\tasks.json VERBOSE: Processing formats\readme.txt VERBOSE: Processing functions\private VERBOSE: Processing functions\public VERBOSE: Processing functions\private\readme.txt VERBOSE: Processing functions\public\readme.txt VERBOSE: Processing tests\readme.txt VERBOSE: Processing types\readme.txt VERBOSE: Exporting module layout to c:\work\layout.json. PS C:\>

dev:remarks.maml:para: Export the directory layout defined under C:\Work\sample to a c:\work\layout.json.

maml:description.maml:para: Format a function name to proper case.

Format-FunctionName is intended to be used as a helper function in your scripting automation. This is a simple function that will format a verb-noun function name into proper case. It will take an input such as test-data and format it as Test-Data. It will not format as camel-case. The command also will not verify that the verb component is acceptable. Use Test-FunctionName for that process.
What is the name of your function? It should follow the Verb-Noun naming convention. Although the verb will not be validate.
What is the name of your function? It should follow the Verb-Noun naming convention. Although the verb will not be validate.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Format-FunctionName test-data Test-Data

dev:remarks.maml:para: Format the lower-case command name to proper case.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Format-FunctionName try-pssystem Try-Pssystem

dev:remarks.maml:para: The command does not validate the verb nor can it produce a camel-case result like Try-PsSystem.

maml:description.maml:para: Get a defined function alias.

Get-FunctionAlias is tool you can use in your scripting automation. It will extract function names and aliases from a PowerShell script file. The source must be a .ps1 or .psm1 file. The command will only idenfity aliases defined as part of the function using code like [alias('foo')].
Specify the .ps1 or .psm1 file with defined functions.
Specify the .ps1 or .psm1 file with defined functions.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-FunctionAlias -Path C:\scripts\SQLBackup.psm1
Name Alias ---- ----- Backup-SQLDatabase Backup-SQL Restore-SQLdatabase rsql

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get functions and aliases from the specified file.

maml:description.maml:para: Get function attributes like cmdletbinding.
This command can be used to get function attributes such as cmdletbinding or alias settings.
Specify the name of the PowerShell function.
Specify the path to the .ps1 or .psm1 file.
Display the attribute block as a string.
Specify the name of the PowerShell function.
Specify the path to the .ps1 or .psm1 file.
Display the attribute block as a string.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-Functionattribute -path c:\scripts\PSFunctionTools\functions\public\Get-ParameterBlock.ps1 -Name get-parameterblock
Type : cmdletbinding NamedArguments : {} PositionalArguments : {} String : [cmdletbinding()] Function : Get-Parameterblock Path : C:\scripts\PSFunctionTools\functions\public\Get-ParameterB lock.ps1
Type : alias NamedArguments : {} PositionalArguments : {"gpb"} String : [alias("gpb")] Function : Get-Parameterblock Path : C:\scripts\PSFunctionTools\functions\public\Get-ParameterB lock.ps1
Type : OutputType NamedArguments : {} PositionalArguments : {"ParamBlockAst", "String"} String : [OutputType("ParamBlockAst","String")] Function : Get-Parameterblock Path : C:\scripts\PSFunctionTools\functions\public\Get-ParameterB lock.ps1

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get detailed function attributes.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-Functionattribute -path c:\scripts\New-OneDriveLink.ps1 -name new-onedrivelink -ToString [cmdletbinding(SupportsShouldProcess)] [alias("odl")]

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get function attributes as a string.

maml:description.maml:para: Identify the names of PowerShell functions in a PowerShell script file.

When exporting functions from files, you may only want to export specific functions. Which you can do if you know the name. Use Get-FunctionName to identify the names of functions. The default behavior is to get names of functions that follow the verb-noun naming convention.
Specify the .ps1 or .psm1 file with defined functions.
List all detected function names regardless of naming convention.
Write a rich detailed object to the pipeline.
List all detected function names regardless of naming convention.
Specify the .ps1 or .psm1 file with defined functions.
Write a rich detailed object to the pipeline.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-FunctionName C:\scripts\MyInternetTools.psm1 Get-MyWhoIs Get-GeoIP Get-MyPublicIP Get-MyWeather Get-WeatherByProxy Get-WeatherLocation Get-QOTD Get-ZipInfo Get-RSSFeed Open-URL

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the names of all standard functions in the specified file.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-FunctionName C:\scripts\MyInternetTools.psm1 _log _parseOutput Get-MyWhoIs Get-GeoIP Get-MyPublicIP Get-MyWeather Get-WeatherByProxy Get-WeatherLocation Get-QOTD Get-ZipInfo Get-RSSFeed Open-URL

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the names of all functions in the specified file regardless of naming convention.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-FunctionName C:\scripts\Convert-FunctionToFile.ps1 -Detailed
Path: C:\scripts\Convert-FunctionToFile.ps1
Name ---- Export-FunctionFromFile Get-FunctionAlias Get-FunctionName Test-FunctionName

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get detailed output from the command which includes the path to source file.

maml:description.maml:para: Get a function's parameter block.
This command is designed to use the PowerShell AST and retrieve a function's parameter block. You might use this to build comment-based help.
Specify the name of the PowerShell function.
Specify the path to the .ps1 or .psm1 file.
Display the parameter block as a string.
Specify the name of the PowerShell function.
Specify the path to the .ps1 or .psm1 file.
Display the parameter block as a string.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\Scripts> Get-parameterblock -path c:\scripts\SimpleFunction.ps1 -name Get-FolderData
Attributes Parameters Extent ---------- ---------- ------ {} {$Path, $Cutoff, $Filter} Param (…

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the AST parameter block object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\Scripts> Get-parameterblock -path c:\scripts\SimpleFunction.ps1 -name Get-FolderData -ToString [parameter(HelpMessage = "Specify the folder to analyze")] [string]$Path="." [datetime]$Cutoff [string]$Filter="*.*"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the parameter block for the given function as a string.

maml:description.maml:para: List PowerShell command requirements.

As part of your scripting automation, you may want to capture requirements defined in a script file such as '# requires -version 5.1'. Get-PSRequirements will process a PowerShell script file for these type of requirements.
The path to your PowerShell script file. It must be a .ps1 or .psm1 file.
The path to your PowerShell script file. It must be a .ps1 or .psm1 file.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: If you run this command in the PowerShell console or VS Code, and elevation is required, the 'True' value will be displayed in green.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a module structure from a layout file.
Use Import-ModuleLayout to recreate a module structure from a json file created with Export-ModuleLayout. Importing the json file will recreate the folders and files.
What is the name of your new module?
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specify the path to the module layout json file.
What is the parent path? The default is the current location
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specify the path to the module layout json file.
What is the name of your new module?
What is the parent path? The default is the current location
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Import-ModuleLayout -Name PSDemo -ParentPath D:\scripts -Layout C:\work\layout.json
Directory: C:\scripts\PSDemo
Mode LastWriteTime Length Name ---- ------------- ------ ---- d---- 12/16/2021 9:45 AM types d---- 12/16/2021 9:45 AM .github d---- 12/16/2021 9:45 AM .vscode d---- 12/16/2021 9:45 AM docs ... Directory: D:\scripts\PSDemo\functions
Mode LastWriteTime Length Name ---- ------------- ------ ---- d---- 12/16/2021 9:45 AM public d---- 12/16/2021 9:45 AM private
Directory: D:\scripts\PSDemo\functions\public
Mode LastWriteTime Length Name ---- ------------- ------ ---- -a--- 12/16/2021 9:49 AM 276 readme.txt ...

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create the directory structure from C:\work\layout.json under a new path of D:\scripts\PSDemo. The parent path, D:\scripts, must already exist.

maml:description.maml:para: Create comment based help.

You can use this command in your scripting automation to generate a comment-based help block for a function. The function will use the parameter block which you can get with Get-ParameterBlock to define help parameters. If your parameter has a HelpMessage defined, the value will be used in the parameter description.
You can also specify a synopsis and/or description. Otherwise, you can edit the placeholders later.
A parameter block AST object. Use Get-ParameterBlock.
Provide a longer description. You can always edit this later.
Provide a short description. You can always edit this later.
Provide a longer description. You can always edit this later.
Provide a short description. You can always edit this later.
Insert a standard help template without any parameter definitions.
A parameter block AST object. Use Get-ParameterBlock.
Provide a longer description. You can always edit this later.
Provide a short description. You can always edit this later.
Insert a standard help template without any parameter definitions.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-Parameterblock -path c:\scripts\SimpleFunction.ps1 -name Get-FolderData | New-CommentHelp -Synopsis "Get folder details" <# .Synopsis Get folder details .Description <long description> .Parameter Path Specify the folder to analyze .Parameter Cutoff <enter a parameter description> .Parameter Filter <enter a parameter description> .Example PS C:\> <output and explanation> .Inputs <Inputs to this function (if any)> .Outputs <Output from this function (if any)> .Notes <General notes> .Link <enter a link reference> #>

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example is getting the parameter block for the specified function and creating comment-base help. The Path parameter has a HelpMessage defined so that value is used in the help. You would need to fill in your own descriptions for the other parameters.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a PowerShell module from a set of files.

New-ModuleFromFiles is an experimental function. It is not guaranteed to run without error and may change significantly between module versions. The command is designed to process a collection of PowerShell script files which contain PowerShell functions. Each function will be exported to an individual file to a location you specify.
The function relies on a module layout file to scaffold the module directory.

If you have the Platyps module installed, you can also choose to create help documentation. If you have git installed, you can initialize the module as a git repository. This process will also checkout a new branch.
What is the name of the new module?
What is the parent path for the new module? It must already exist.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Create help documentation using the Platyps module. This is a dynamic parameter that only exists if the Platyps module is detected.
Enter a module description.

Enter the paths to PowerShell script files with functions to export. These should be files with a .ps1 or .psm1 extension. Only functions with valid verb-noun names will be exported. Each function be exported to an individual file.
Specify the relative path for the exported functions. This should be in your module layout.
Initialize the new module as a git repository. This is a dynamic parameter that only exists if git is detected. This process will also checkout a new branch.
Specify the module layout json file created with Export-ModuleLayout.
Specify the path for the markdown help files. This is a dynamic parameter that only exists if the Platyps module is detected. You can specify location that is in your module layout.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Create help documentation using the Platyps module. This is a dynamic parameter that only exists if the Platyps module is detected.
Enter a module description.

Enter the paths to PowerShell script files with functions to export. These should be files with a .ps1 or .psm1 extension. Only functions with valid verb-noun names will be exported. Each function be exported to an individual file.
Specify the relative path for the exported functions. This should be in your module layout.
Initialize the new module as a git repository. This is a dynamic parameter that only exists if git is detected. This process will also checkout a new branch.
Specify the module layout json file created with Export-ModuleLayout.
Specify the path for the markdown help files. This is a dynamic parameter that only exists if the Platyps module is detected. You can specify location that is in your module layout.
What is the name of the new module?
What is the parent path for the new module? It must already exist.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $splat = @{ Description = "Demo exported module" Files = "c:\scripts\pstools.psm1","c:\scripts\servertools.ps1" Layout = "c:\scripts\ModuleLayout.json" NewModuleName = "PSTools" ParentPath = "c:\scripts" CreateHelp = $True FunctionPath = "functions\public" InitializeGit = $true } PS C:\> New-ModuleFromFiles @splat

dev:remarks.maml:para: Using the parameter values defined in the hashtable, create a new module called PSTools using the functions from pstools.psm1 and servertools.ps1. Only functions with valid verb-noun names will be exported. This example will also create initial help documentation and initialize a git repository.

maml:description.maml:para: Creat a new module based on a layout.

This command is very similar to New-ModuleFromFiles. That function builds a module structure from existing files. This function creates a new module but without defining any commands. New-ModuleFromLayout will still create a module structure based on a layout and it will still create module files. Specifically,the module manifest and root module files.
If git.exe is detected, you can use the InitializeGit dynamic parameter to initialize the module as a git repository.
What is the name of the new module?
What is the parent path for the new module? It must already exist.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Enter a module description.
Specify the relative path where your functions will be created.
Initialize the new module as a git repository. This is a dynamic parameter that only exists if git.exe is detected.
Specify the module layout json file created with Export-ModuleLayout.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Enter a module description.
Specify the relative path where your functions will be created.
Initialize the new module as a git repository. This is a dynamic parameter that only exists if git.exe is detected.
Specify the module layout json file created with Export-ModuleLayout.
What is the name of the new module?
What is the parent path for the new module? It must already exist.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-ModuleFromLayout -NewModuleName PSDataResource -ParentPath c:\scripts -Description "A class-based DSC resource to do something." -Layout .c:\scripts\DSCModuleLayout.json

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a new and empty module under C:\Scripts\PSDataResource using the layout file c:\scripts\dscmodulelayout.json.

maml:description.maml:para: Test the validity of a PowerShell function name.

PowerShell function names should follow naming convention of Verb-Noun. The verb should be a standard verb that you see with Get-Verb. Use this command in your scripting automation to validate a PowerShell function name.
If the name passes validation it will be written to the pipeline. Or you can use the -Quiet parameter to return a traditional boolean result.
Specify a function name.
Get a boolean test result.
Specify a function name.
Get a boolean test result.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Test-FunctionName Test-Widget Test-Widget

dev:remarks.maml:para: Because the name passes validation, it is written to the pipeline.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Test-FunctionName -Name stop-foo | Format-FunctionName Stop-Foo

dev:remarks.maml:para: Test the function name and format the result.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Test-FunctionName kill-system -Quiet False

dev:remarks.maml:para: Test with boolean result.
